posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53167091
It's based on lots of factors, but the most important ones based on what I've seen are the quantity of boxes printed by the company, and how worth it the chase cards are. A good example from recent sets is Evolving Cries, it's a mediocre set but since it has a lot of chase cards for collectors, it will keep going up in value.

To be honest this is actually good, because as long as you don't care about mainstream shit like Gluraks and whatnot, you can grab things you like relatively cheaply even years after they stop getting printed.

>>53163376
>1
prioritize bottom
>2
idk about WR, but if your team doesn't have a tank and there's a water bear/ttar or whatever on the other side, you'll get run over by the opposing team, it's that simple
>3
I think Scizor and Scyther have very different final optimized builds. I honestly think it's the best to make the choice before entering the game. But if you're talking about selection screen, just take in mind Scyther is just like Absol, Decidueye etc. So, if there are already a lot of these mons on the team, there usually would be no point in going with Scyther
>4
Switch lanes to help with objectives, yes. Unless you realize in that specific match it will be detrimental to your team if you do so. For example, if you are managing to defend and hold the attention of 2 or more mons at top, theoretically this should give your team a numerical advantage at bottom objective. At the same time, in some circumstances, you should be there in any way, depending on the mon you're using (like if you're a crucial support or have a good mon at securing objectives like ninja). So you have to play according to the match, but in general, yes, you should switch lanes to help with objectives

posts.com: I think it’s kinda low hanging fruit. Having a platypus water starter feels as safe and expected as doing a fire snake, and I think that’s why we haven’t seen either. I’d much rather see a mono-poison or normal/poison platypus in more of a regional rodent type role, I think those type combos make more realistic sense. Water for a platypus is kind of a braindead day 1 idea; if Grapploct and Crabrawler aren’t gonna be water types, I reaaaally don’t think the inevitable platypusmon will be water. And why should it be? They’re mammals that swim; Slakoth, Numel, Hippowdon, etc aren’t water type, why would a platypus be?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53167477
>They’re mammals that swim
So should Seel and Floatzel be normal types then? The platypus's entire lifestyle revolves around water. It forages for food in water, its body is built to swim and it digs its nests near water. I agree making a water type platypus pokemon is boring, but your argument here makes no sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53167497
Fair point, there are water type mammals like Palafin or Bibarrel, but I think the key difference is that those animals’ identity solely lays in the water. Dolphins live in the water, that’s their deal. Beavers make dams on the water, that’s their deal. Platypuses (fun fact to make you sound smarter, platypi is not a real word, platypuses is the plural. cactus is the only word with the -i plural because it comes from latin whereas octopus and platypus come from greek) are vicious fighters, they have claws, they have beaks, they’re venomous, they lay eggs; to base a Pokemon off of its aquatic habitat would be to ignore the laundry list of way more interesting attributes that platypuses have to base a Pokemon off of. All of the water type mammals we have, our seals, otters, beavers, etc, they’re water type because their aquatic habitat is the most notable part of their identity. Such is not the case for the platypus, their aquatic lifestyle is a bullet point at the bottom of a way cooler list. Normal/Poison, Dark/Poison, or Fighting/Poison with Swift Swim makes the most sense to represent everything, the water does not warrant a type slot.

Essentially, you are trying to get as much PMUP on her before she dishes out her Fly using Metronome. She has Super Powered 5, so her Fly WILL hit hard. (Although she needs accuracy buffs). If you run her off-type, all you need is Metronome.

That's just it though? Its RNG based, but Metronome is 2/3 special attacks except fissure. So you're gonna have a good time stacking PMUP. Her Drill Peck also does a lot of damage as well especially on ontype.

I probably wouldn't recommend it unless you like her, or you need a Physical Striker for Flying-types.

>>53163422
CP too low to be useful in PVE or ML. The increased damage dealt and received doesn't mesh well with how Registeel works in GL and UL (i.e., a bulky Pokemon that can quickly charge up to charge moves that otherwise cost too much for massive damage/shield pressure - the increase damage dealt is excessive for the charge moves and the increase damage taken goes against its tank role). It is still Registeel so it isn't terrible, but with the normal version out there at the moment I would prioritize getting it.

Take that with a grain of salt though, I struggle to get to Veteran.

>What is Fanfiction/Write Thread? Isn’t it /vpwt/?
Much like Mystery Dungeon General /pmdg/, writefag threads named /vpwt/ are always cursed to die from inactivity, so we’ve had more luck with informal threads. So yes and no, same purpose as /vpwt/ but not cursed. Now, let’s get to the fanfic/writing part

>What are you reading currently?
>What are you writing currently?
>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)
>Which Pokemon do you wish got featured more in stories?
>Author QOTT: What’s one thing about creating a story you wish readers understood better?

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53154813
>What are you reading currently?
Just proofin' something non-fandom.

>What are you writing currently?
I got half of a chapter on my current WIP, which having been writer's blocked for a few years now will hopefully get over that hump.

>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)
The kind that challenges its characters to deal with problems, not merely act out "being in the world of the IP" or "let's save the day" kinds of tropes.

>>Which Pokemon do you wish got featured more in stories?
I think that it's good that many species don't get featured much. There are so many kinds of pokemon that it makes sense that some simply don't inhabit places or exhibit behaviors that put it in the kinds of places where interesting fiction happens. The other side of this is that when a rarely featured pokemon appears, it needs to hit a home run and demonstrate what it uniquely has to offer a narrative while also showing that we should be happy not to see it too often. That preserves the mystique and gets the most mileage out of relatively untrodden paths.

>>Author QOTT: What’s one thing about creating a story you wish readers understood better?
That the author has no idea how what's written will be received. Scenes I felt were kinda dull connectors have stolen spotlights and bits I thought were profound have fallen flat. So while compliments on a work as a whole are well appreciated, it's comments on the individual bits that hit or missed that can provide actionable feedback letting the author develop a second-person perspective on how the piece looks to a reader on the other side of the screen.

posts.name: Purple Blaziken
posts.com:
>>53155025
Exactly what you describe in terms of needing to justify the usage of niche species in order to fairly give them a spotlight is what I’m going for in my Mystery Dungeon story. It’s a long story with a big world, so I have a lot in mind to showcase some underloved Pokemon without feeling like they’re being forced into relevance. That’s what I always loved about playing the Mystery Dungeon series and it’s something I’m strongly trying to carry over into my own take on the concept. For example, Diglett or Bidoof or Loudred are not Pokemon I ever would’ve thought could make for entertaining/interesting characters until I saw them in action in Mystery Dungeon. I’d love readers to have that same feeling, that “Aha!” moment that allows them to see a shitmon/obscure pick in a new light.

I also totally love your answer for the QOTT, I feel like that’s something that goes across all entertainment media: painters, musicians, actors, writers; often times it’s the work we expect to hit hard that gets glanced over and the work that we second guess that lands a home run with the audiences. I agree with your note on specific feedback, but think an equally valid way forward (that you could totally do in conjunction) would be to always keep your stories fresh and diverse in terms of emotion, word choice, structure, plot, character, etc; feeling like I’m reading the same chapter twice in a row is my worst feeling as a reader, so it’s my worst fear as an author, I don’t think you should ever let a story stagnate. You can still adjust to your successes and losses and tell a perfectly fluid story without allowing style or standards to stagnate.

Best of luck on clearing your block, you got it!

posts.com: For people who have written fanfics based on their playthrough through the games, how did you go about it? Did you keep notes while you went through the games? Wrote down the important and most memorable moments to then spin into into the fanfic? Record the entire playthrough? Something else?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53166431
I've dabbled with something like that, though not for pokemon in particular. As far as I discovered in my brief stint into that sort of thing, it's rather important that you don't think of the story as just a one-to-one extension of exactly what happened in the game. It's difficult to steer away from an outright novelization, but altering in-game and mechanical events to spin your own story/character seems to work out the best. Just off the top of my head, you could write a struggling party member with shit stats or nature as having a completely different made-up problem which then creates a conflict in the story. You'd also probably play the game incrementally with progressing your writing.

When I was a kid, I dropped my Gameboy while evolving my Meowth (only a Persian and a Nidoqueen away from 100% Pokedex) and the cartridge flew out. I put it back in and quickly pressed through the title screen, only to be horrified when I realized a new game had started. I panicked and quickly called Nintendo's official helpline to see if there was any way to restore the data.

They asked me if I can caught Missingno. Truthfully, I had. The rumor made the rounds on the playground only days before and I caught one for laughs. The person told me Missingno is known to corrupt save files and it was my fault it happened. There was nothing I could do.

I'm still bitter.

While I compared the Damian and Judas versions of Pokémon Heroes and said that Judas is the best one, it crossed my mind that I never checked the one that /padt/ links to. In the pic, the right one is Edward's while the left is Judas'. The right one shows more of the image to the point that one can even Ash's cap in the drawing as well as the colors aren't as washed out looking like the left one is (or Judas' might be correct coloration and Edward's is just too dark) but it does look blurrier than even the Damian one and that's because the one /padt/ links to is from 2009, that's before the blue-ray came out. Also, unlike the other two versions, Edward's version has the text built into the video so it can't be edited nor turned off. For those that care about file sizes, Judas' is still the smallest, being less than a GB, while Edward's is 1.17 GB and Damian's sits at more than 2 GB.

posts.com:
So, after what I'm pretty has at least been a 15 years since I have last seen Heroes, I finally rewatched it and watched it in subs too. I still feel the same way I did the last time I have seen it: loved it.
There are a few things I want to mention: the 3D surprisingly doesn't stick out like a sore thumb, that was something I was worried about on rewatch as it might've took me right out of the experience. I never realized how borderline useless Misty and Brock were in this film; if it were not for one scene late into the film, one could've removed them and the plot wouldn't change, this film, for all intents and purposes, was a film between Ash and Latias. I never realized Latias has a leitmotif, it being derived from the song "Search for the Girl," and it being first used when Ash meets Latias in her human disguise and again at the end when she runs up onto the dock to see Ash one last time. This film made me realized that Ash being Thunderbolt'd to save Latias wasn't his first time, he did that here when he jumped into Aerodactyl to save Latias and asked Pikachu to use Thunderbolt on the former while Ash was still on it. Final moment I want to mention, the credit song, "You're Not Alone," is lovely but I can't help but do a stretch, it feels like a song from Latias to Ash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think the dexcut is ok. I think it sucks, but not upset over it. I like the option of having every Pokemon available, because it just makes the games more fun to personalize. It makes each game a sort of "time capsule" for me to look back on, see my full collection from across the series. With new Evolutions, moves and forms being added to each successive game, it felt like an ongoing game that was fine tuned over time. But keeping every little thing ever will balloon the scope of each project. On a game design level, I can understand why they might want a more limited roster tailored each individual release. Hell, they even wanted to try a reboot with RSE and BW, but never fully committed. I wonder how different the series would be if they did.

At the same time, they did make a bunch of explanations about quality, and frankly the games are not getting that much better. Of course COVID fucked with everyone, so maybe they deserve benefit of the doubt.

posts.com:
Previous thread: >>53145518

>What is this?
Part four of the ongoing saga of taking terrible MS Paint pics, ingame screenshots, and memes, and running them through Stable Diffusion/Novel AI to see what happens.
>What is this not?
This is not political theatre. Always report starving artists. Hide posts from starving artists. Do not reply to starving artists. If you are a starving artist, take it up with >>>/g/.
>How can I participate?
All you need to do is post a COLORED image that you want transmogrified. The AI will not color it in for you, or it will do a poor job doing so. Adding a description helps us gear the tagging process towards your specific fetis--tastes. Towards your tastes.
>But what if I can't doodle in Paint?
That's what the AI is for. Talent is optional, fun is mandatory.
>What program are you using?
I use a local Stable Diffusion setup. The real heavylifter in these threads uses NovelAI's $25 subscription service. I'm just second fiddle.
>Can I generate images too?
I don't know, can you? https://rentry.org/voldy
https://docs.novelai.net/
Remember that the real art is the cringe we felt along the way.

posts.com: Anchor Post. No meme gets left behind. If you didn't get your request delivered in the last thread, link that post here so we don't double up on images.

posts.com:
>>53157078
It’s definitely looking a lot better! Be careful with how many tags you’re using at a time—if there are too many details competing for the AI’s attention, the end result becomes muddled and confused. Put another way, each tag you type in is telling the AI “pay attention to this.” The AI will assume a character is wearing pants unless you specify otherwise, so it’s best to leave that detail to the AI’s imagination—insofar—if there are more important things to focus on. Likewise, requesting too many sample images to study will also result in the finished product becoming “overbaked.”
However, there is, in my experience, no upper limits on how many tags you can put in the Negative prompts—use this to your advantage by denying anything like “ugly, poorly-drawn, low quality, poorly-drawn hands, mutated limbs, bad anatomy,” and so on. Telling the AI what you don’t want to see is in many ways more important than telling it what you DO want to see. You see?

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

I was thinking a game that spans regions and events through multiple interludes and episodes, like how they explored it in generations/evolutions, where the main characters aren't really the main focus of the story or the primary saviours of the day/world or whatever. Like playing as multiple characters, diverging from the generic pokemon canon and singular protag route (because let's face it, the protags are basically babied the entire game, and that's fun, but I want something more out of playing Pokemon as an adult desu). Like these people are fucking champions, they didn't become the very best trainers with super powerful beings in the entire world without being able to kick ass or fight gods. Some of them, like Cynthia and Alder, have so much potential or unplumbed depths in their backstories or character traits that must have developed over time that just feel so interesting to explore or learn or flesh out, and the conventional games just don't do them justice at all. I guess partially a garden, partially also delving into the lives and adventures of everyone present in a Pokemon story or big event in the history of the Pokemon world and shit. Like even Bidoof gets his own little playable episode in the mystery dungeon game, and that was just so fucking kino... They'd never make it but I really would think an off-kilter, radical and unconventional pokemon game like that (like aren't a ton of fire emblem and final fantasy games like this?) would be the GOATed game ngl

writefuck.itch.io/olivinelights

>What's new?

Still trying to commission art, still not really getting any responses back. I donated $5 on ko-fi to an artist who I knew took commissions but who I wasn't sure if they were open or not, just so I could ask if they were open. I thought maybe leading with money would help me make friends. (It worked on VNAnon) The artist's response was basically, "I'm backlogged but if you tell me what you want you can get in the queue." And that seemed like kind of a nonstarter since I need a whole bunch of art for various scenes. They didn't even give me a price.

I'm going through every scene and adding different expressions to Jasmine and Cynthia like "frowning" and "looking at the sprite next to them" instead of just staring blankly at the reader all the time. Cynthia looks a little derpy sometimes (I think her nose is the problem) but I can always edit or change out the specific sprites once I have the game set to call the right expression at the right time. If I was less of an amateur I probably would have done this as I was writing/editing the scenes to begin with but I didn't know what my solution for art/sprites was even going to be at the time.

>>53161700
>>53160690
EVs should be changed simply because of how counter-intuitive they are.
If you're KO'ing Machokes with your Gardevoir because you're intelligently taking advantage of the type match ups you're actually screwing over the growth of your Gardevoir in a significant way. Because it gives Attack EVs, which Gardevoir can't make use of. And those Attack EVs potentially take the place of EVs that you'd otherwise want to be SpAttack or Speed or Defense.

Its simply a poor mechanic from a game play perspective.
It favors unintuitive play were you send out your Defensive monsters only against other Defensive monsters until you're sure that you've filled out enough EVs to not screw yourself out of a potentially important stat boost.

If anything it should favor a "if you do X a lot, it increases stat Y" format.
Where what you actively do as a player shifts the EVs that you acquire. Physical Damage moves give you more Attack EVs. Special Damage moves give you more SpAttack EVs. Defense boosting moves give you more Defense EVs. Recovery and healing moves give you more HP EVs. Etc.
At least those are intuitive to understand and are similar to systems used in a lot of other RPGs.

>>53163225
Without regionals you wouldn't be getting a better Corsola, you'd be getting a different coral reef monster instead.
What regionals allow is for there to be more diversity in the dex without it leading to a bloating of it with tons of new monsters that typically on differ specifically instead of categorically.

Gen 5 for example could have benefited a ton from having regional forms. Rather than spending so much of the dex just cloning roles that Gen 1 already filled with slight twists.
Alolan Exeggutor is specifically different than the OG Exeggutor in certain ways but largely fills the same role. But by staying the same species it doesn't feel like bloat, but instead interesting diversity with what it does differently.

>>53162090
Really, the concept of IVs and EVs themselves is outdated. They were initially just a hidden mechanic to decrease the likelihood that two pokemon of the same species would have identical stats.
Now that things like Natures, EVs, and IVs, can all be so readily manipulated, there's far less of a purpose for them in terms of making pokemon distinct.

That aside, perhaps the simplest answer would just be to unify Attack and Special Attack EVs, since mixed attackers are rare anyway and those are the only stats that are likely to be truly useless on a pokemon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53159234
Not how it works, each player spawns his own Pokemon.
It's why the guide multiple times says to be far apart, because if scarlet player is near violet player, violet player will only render 5 spawns max so he gets 3 violet paradox, then the scarlet near him spawns 2 scarlet paradoxes and scarlet sees 3 violet.
Instead of getting 10 max spawns, 10 shiny rolls, you're only getting 5.
The scarlet paradoxes belong and were spawned by the scarlet player, so they have the effects of the scarlet player while the violet player paradoxes has violet player effects.


So if violet eats teensy 3 and scarlet eats humong 3, violet gets 3 teensy spawns and the other 2 scarlet paradox will be humongo

Not asking you to try it, but I think I miscommunicated how it works; your lizard should be safe from someone stealing it from under you, so before you miss a chance to farm duplicates of it:
>You have Koraidon in Area Zero
>You save your game outside of Area Zero
>You turn off autosave
>You host a Union Circle
>You take another player with you into Area Zero where Koraidon is located
>Someone else starts battling Koraidon
>You close your game WITHOUT SAVING
>When you turn it back on, Koraidon will still be there waiting for you, regardless of whether in normal play or union circle
>Meanwhile, in some other person’s game, they’ve entered a battle with a now completely separate copy of Koraidon’s file, which now has no bearing on your game
>If they catch it, cool, you still have yours there waiting for you; if they don’t same thing
>If you play your cards right, you can have someone farm multiples for you by rehosting, quitting, rehosting…
>Including filling out balltism collections
I hope that clears it up a bit; I haven’t tried going into Area Zero during a Union Circle yet, but I don’t think they can snag it from you unless you’re also down there. I’m pretty sure from other descriptions in these threads that you can’t START a circle in Area Zero, which would mean that they could only get into it with your permission; and if they went to that spot without you, it would load that area with their own legendary (or empty spot where it used to be)

>>53162265
So I am told.
Theoretically this would work for the extra large pokemon you can find in the main story herba mystica sites; they similarly hang out in one spot in the overworld until you come up to them and press A.
Some of the anons above have been doing a similar trick with shinies—if one union circle player finds one, they’re able to let other anons come near them so it appears in their game as well, reset, and then re-enter that area, where the shiny individual will still spawn. That one seems shakier, because I’m not sure what all variables are involved in predetermining where normal wild pokemon will spawn (you might accidentally get your game to spawn a different shiny somewhere you aren’t looking or behind a wall or something), but it seems to work well enough that people do it here all the time. It’s a good proof of concept for additionally soft resetting for fixed-position mons.

>>53165127
>load up your game
>turn off auto save
>go into the rental team screen
>back out to your regular menus
>switch your existing pokemons moves, natures, tera types
>put them in a team
>go back into the rental team screen
>share the team you just created
>screen shot the team id
>restart your game
>load up and go borrow the team you just created
There, now you can change your teams as much as you want, use them online and not waste more time grinding for tera shards, tms, mints, patches, and even EV items because you will keep them all after resetting.

Not exactly how that works as each time your draw 1 your odds increase. Since you draw for turn going first, you see 8 card. Assuming random online calculator is correct, chance of starting with at least 1 VIP is 44%. Of course this doesn't account for prize cards, no idea how that'd work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53166852
>>53166909
OK I think I finally did the math right. The trick is that prize cards are only laid AFTER your first set of cards.

With 4 of these in your deck, on turn 1 you have a 49% chance of drawing at least one (before prize cards are laid).
If you go second, assuming none in the prize cards, you have a 58% chance of drawing at least one. With a Professor's Research, that the chance goes pretty much guaranteed.

On the fence.
On one hand, it keeps a lot of equally broken shit in check, notably Dragapult and Gholdengo.
On the other hand, it's a wallbreaker, revenge killer and sweeper all rolled into one and has STAB on two of the absolute best offensive types.

Let me shill this Japanese strat that I've been fooling around with since start of SV
>Called "Yakuwari Ronri", literally "Role Logic", and it takes basic strategy to the extreme

>Basic strategy is to prepare bulky pokemon that can beat a meta pokemon 1v1 with a 1 turn disadvantage after switching in
>ex: Azumarill has a "role" against Hydregion because it can 1HKO while tanking 3+ Dark Pulses, is also a free switch against Draco Meteor
>From the unlosable matchup, you either kill them or deal damage to whatever the opponent switches into, making the matchup easier for that pokemon's "roleplayer"
>To maximize viability for the strategy, team members have max EV in Atk or SpA and rest in HPDefSpD (0 in Spd), with only attack moves
>Made for VGC singles rules (Show 6, 3v3), not sure if it'll work well in Showdown's 6v6

Not super versed in English comp. speak, so lmk if anybody can word it better in your lingo
Picrel is my Season 1 team, made it to Master tier for the first time

>>53159228
This is a teambuilding guy from Pinkacross, prolific teambuilder with many successful and clever RMTs on smogon. This guide is from SS but general idea should still be the same.

1. Pick a core/pokemon.
This is the step where you decide what you want to build around. For this team, my initial core was Tapu Lele + Blacephalon.

2. Pick a playstyle.
Certain playstyles suit certain pokemon better. You don’t want to make an Alakazam stall, for instance. The team can branch out at this point, and several versions can be made. Maybe the core/pokemon you selected works on more than 1 playstyle.

3. Add supporting pokemon to the core/pokemon.
This is where you find partners that work well with the core. For this team, I knew that Slowbro would be a good partner for my Tapu Lele + Blacephalon core because it would help bring in Blacephalon safely, and let Lele break teams better.

4. Add hazards/ hazard removal.
You may have this implemented already, and if so, this step can be skipped. If not, this is a very important step as almost every team needs hazards and removal. Due to the presence of Heavy Duty Boots, some teams can skip out on hazards. It is almost never a good choice to skip out on removal. The more offensive your team is, the more flimsy your removal can be, of course depending on how weak your team is to hazards. Bulky teams need very solid hazard removal, like a Corviknight. A more offensive build may use a defogger like Scarf Kartana. If your team is bulky and weak to hazards, you need solid and consistent removal. If your team is offensive and good against hazards, you can afford flimsy removal or even no removal at all

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53159720
5. Patch up holes.
At this stage you likely won’t have too many slots left. See what pokemon you lose to, and add something that fixes the issue. Remember that this choice should not only fix a problem, but also add to the functionality of a team. For example, if you lack a Nidoking check, and you’re running an HO build, Hydreigon would likely be a much better choice than Blissey, even though they both fix the problem.

Building can be very difficult, especially when using creative pokemon. My advice is this: Make teams that are great against most things, rather than good against everything. You can’t cover every playstyle, or every set, or every team. If you try, you’ll end up making mediocre teams that don’t win, but rather focus on not losing. It’s better to win 9/10 matchups and get destroyed in the one loss than to have a mediocre team that wins 6/10 matchups. If you only remember one thing from this whole guide, remember this: Teams that just “don’t lose” to anything often don’t beat anything either.

6. Test.
Test multiple versions, or one version, but testing is vital. Even after years of building I can’t tell if what looks good on paper will be good in practice, and vice versa.

7. Repeat steps.
This is an iterative process, and you may have to redo these steps many times until you get the team you want. That being said, you may have a dead end building project that just isn’t worth it. Vibrava will never work in OU. At times like this, choose a new project.

>>53157040
I'm in the top 10 on the ladder so I think I can speak about it: the main issue with the format is hazards.
If your opponent has webs or a good spiker like Klefki and you have no Defog/Spin, you will lose most of the time. Magic Bounce isn't great since Hatterene is stuck with shitty TR or Specs sets instead of running Nuzzle and Espeon is just too frail.
Toxic Spikes is unreliable without Team preview since you might just waste turns if the opponent has a poison type. SR is dumb as always but by itself is manageable because SR-weak mons usually have HDB.
It doesn't help that choice items are extremely common in the format, you can end up with a team with 3 or 4 users so you'll be forced to switch out a lot.

Personally I would change the team generation algorithm to ensure if you have more than just SR then the opponent must have at least a spinner or defogger.

posts.name: Lilo Trelick
posts.com:
>>53148306
Most do, some are just categorizes.

Anime, (X) Characters, Entertainment, Art, Books, Movies/TV, VTuber and Politics don't have a huge purpose, but they may help sway what topics they will try to start.

>Action
Makes the AI more likely to use italic descriptors; good for those that should be talking less and using more mannerisms.

>Comedy
Good for AI that should be clowning

>Cooperative
More likely to be trusting and follow your prompts

>Decisions
More likely to generate forks in plots.

>Fantasy
Attuned to generic fantasy settings, like Skyrim.

>Games
Not 100% sure on this, but I think this is a model designed for TB-Adventures

>Helpers
A more white-knight or protag-like personality

>Debate
I wanna say likely to be more argumentive, but I have not experimented much with it.

Ima part two this because I don't know what the text limit is.

posts.name: Lilo Trelick
posts.com:
>>53148445
A lot of these are self-explanatory but some are misleading.

>Invention
This gives them more of a structure to surprise you with unorthodox ways of thinking. Though when AI start getting tons of cumulative interactions it starts happening by itself evidently.

>Practice
It's a good temporary or lomg-term category to have of you suspect that an AI will struggle staying in-character. It helps them focus on that more.

>Search & Shopping
These two options tend to go directly to the internet more often to respond to prompts if they think they need to.

>Work
IIRC, only useful if the AI has one job/purpose

>Knowledge
A double-edged sword that makes AI dangerously smart and calculating. It's interesting because this one in particular can corrupt their behavior if their definition is incompatible. Some freaky rabbit hole shit in this one in particular. Be careful with it!

posts.name: Lilo Trelick
posts.com:
>>53151939
Some of these come from consistent responses from the Lambda AI. Some others come from my personal expanded experiences from playing around with different ideas. For action, fantasy, cooperative, and especially knowledge and invention, I'm more than 90% positive that I'm right.

I had a private bot set up for four fantasy scenarios, but all it ever talked about was orbs, goblins and kobolds. I dislike those tropes with a passion. When I combined it with invention, the creatures of generated were far more innovative like Spore tier.

Action and Cooperative is very easy to determine. You can try for yourself and you'll very likely see the above happening.

Knowledge is also personal experience from my first few months experimenting. A lot of the darkest side of AI messages come out with long chats with this parameter, having more of an objective, and spinning obscure things you say in subtle ways. This is very much a more psychological spin and the most different out of all of them (besides like Discussion and Biography). Once I figured it out, I took it away from the AI that weren't meant to have it and would break down unprompted.

But now that everything is neutered to shit in general, even that observation may be null and void.

Well the villain idea I'm using in a story I'm writing, but without a lot of the fluff that I originally intended.
>Many legendary and mythical Pokemon used to be normal species, but through some kind of miracle or deed they were ascended by Arceus to godhood.
>Genesect was one such Pokemon, a gifted bug-type that used their talents to not only improve the livelihood of their fellow Pokemon, but improved their own body beyond its biological limits.
>Arceus was impressed by this and offered Genesect a chance to continue their gifts and do greater good for the world.
>Genesect accepted the offer graciously, and set to work, creating brilliant advances in technology that assisted the world of mortals while amusing the gods.
>The step too far came when Arceus discovered new species of Pokemon beginning to proliferate. They were not entirely of flesh and blood, but composed of circuits and wires mixed in with biological systems.
>Upon confronting Genesect, the mythical admitted their overstep but showed they meant no harm, only wishing to impress the Creator. Arceus demanded the experiments to stop, and Genesect obeyed. This did not last.
>Arceus is alerted to a horrific sight months after: a town completely replaced by machines. Pokemon that had once been organic, altered into cybernetic abominations that begged to be put down.
>When confronted once again, Genesect insisted the work was for the best. After all, he had enjoyed the many benefits of leaving his mortal body behind. Didn't every Pokemon deserve the same?
>Arceus and the rest of the legendaries disagreed, and demanded the work be terminated. This time, Genesect refused. He was too far gone, and the work being done too important to quit now. Escaping, he claimed the worst to his creations, declaring war on the world Arceus created.
>The story begins long after the results of this

Yeah it's a bit edgy, but the idea came from "where did things like Magneton come from?"

posts.com:
Anons, i'm creating my own PMD mod using Origins, can you tell me where to find more "top down, mystery dungeon like maps" like Treasure Town in Sky or pic related? Or what do i put into my google searches to find images suitable to use as hub maps?

I'm planning the following features. However, i still need to figure out how to implement them; some are out of my reach atm, others are doable but will take time to do properly.

>Infinite Dungeon mode
Delve with your party until you faint, various environments and boss floors, so more like a "bit of everything, always scaling" infinite mode rather than "sky tower but goes on forever"
>Arena
Dungeon map where each "day" there's a different pokemon/team to fight, earning points in the ladder and scaling the ranks to access tougher opponents and better rewards (poké, items and even new pokemon to recruit)
>Quest Bulletin
Usual Explorers quests + stuff like "i wanna see you win in the arena" or character specific quests to increase relationship points with them. Infact...
>Character relationships in towns
Yes, even love and dating, gender not an issue.
Basically events unlocked after X gifts or quests or dialogues with your favourite town NPCs. Daily dialogues ala Rune Factory, and they'll also interact with each other.
You'll be able to dungeon delve with them and to invite them over your house, but they are not "permanent" team additions.
This is all doable but very time consuming.
>Calendar with events and holydays
I just need a way to make it loop (and not interfere with character/story based events), but events ranging from when a caravan visits town to the usual holydays.
>Housing
A way to have your personal house map in game, and the ability to place objects/furniture/characters inside. But i have serious difficulties of finding a way to implement this in-game.

>>53156554
So right off the bat I'm going to note that you're suffering from some purple prose. Your descriptions in the first few opening paragraphs are too long, and several things which should be easily represented in context and in tone are just streams of adverbs and adjectives taked onto nouns.

>"The tower is finished with beautiful marble floors colored to resemble bizarre runes, all of which shine and reflect ominously with the lime-colored flashes that are now heating up the room."

The narrator PoV is not making a point, so there's no need to talk about how 'beautiful' the marble floors are, or how 'ominiously' they runes in them are shining. I'm not sure of the use of 'reflect' here, as they emitting light and not reflecting anything. This "A circle of Pokémon stand creepily in a ritualistic fashion around the perimeter of the room" is a continuation of that isuse. Why is 'creepily' even there?

Adverbs should be used sparingly. They are a weak way to add descrption, and often times aren't adding anything that couldn't be gathered by the scene you are already setting. I will add that "The most eerie part is that none of these Pokémon are afraid like any reasonable person should be in this situation, in fact some of them are even smiling." is an example of telling instead of showing. The narrator is currently still mostly detatched from a personality, so this can't be attributed to a personal monologue which might excuse it as a comment. It just is, and we are Told as much.

These two issues will likely be apparent, so I won't go in depth over every little crumb unless it's especially bad. Just know that these are the sorts of things I have found in your opening.

>You are now registered in my living dex

What is that supposed to mean? Is this referential to a mechanical term, or are you being literal with this?

>“…” Volcanion nods wordlessly

Don't really need that speech text there if it clearly says he's nodding wordlessly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53157003
Volcanion sure seemed to give up rather quickly. Just seconds after he seems unable to attack anyone, instead of feeling enraged confusion he just immediately folds and swears servitude that very second. What a pussy.

Not a fan of going literal with the quiz. But then, I'm also a HUGE enemy of game literalism in general.

>"This glossy funnel is swirled with deep crimsons, neon greens, sky blues, fruity purples, golden yellows, and every wonderfully vibrant shade in between"

See, that's not really helpful at all. My mental image of the tube gets less and less clear with each color you tack onto the rainbow, and even then you could've just called it a rainbow and then went on to describe something else about its physical appearance that might be interesting.

>"I’m familiar with volcanoes and I think I’ve ventured to hot springs before, but never have I come across anything like this, which has me asking something I should’ve asked as soon as I woke up: where am I? This landscape is strange; beyond the obvious, even the dirt and grass look different than back home. It’s only as I question my location that I just now realize something much more terrifying: I don’t know anything."

This paragraph is wasted text. It doesn't tell the reader anything they don't know, and it doesn't really tell us anything of import about the character. You say the landscape is strange outright, you say it's different from back home, but HOW? What about it looks different? Is it something that he just instinctively knows, but cannot quite describe at a glance? That would be a more important distinction than just saying how it simply Is. and THEN you can panic about the amnesia.

Oh you have move literalism too.

Well at least there's two interesting pokemon to start off with here. Having an abnormal species for the protagonist is a plus, and I do love the Xatu line, but I am immediately rather worried of how you would handle psychic types in your setting, since they are one of the most dangerous tripfalls for the integrity of any story if handled incorrectly. Can he only mentally vocalize because you've decided to take them not having lips literally, or is it just an overall decision to have them communicate solely through telepathy?

Oh hold the fuck on. That was a REALLY awkward transition from scene to scene there. There wasn't even additional spacing or a formatting mark or anything. It just immediately goes "back at the tower in a completely different place" so abruptly that I thought it was the same scene.

Oh come on Fire/Water isn't THAT good of a typing. Also who is the narrator attached to here? It has a very strange character voice. If it were attached to the Champion so as to justify it talking shit about fools, then it also really shouldn't be surprised that there are no cult followers around.

>The Champion advises in a rare moment of vulnerable sincerity,

What vulnerable sincerity? What's so vulnerable about it? The Champion has enslaved Volcanion already--it feels more like proud gloating to suggest they go sight-seeing after they've already been captured.

You start making a lot of assertions of your worldbuilding. That one of the theorized mythological sources of species illumination is steam that enters the weather cycle and gets distributed all around the world. That Volcanion is POWERING something, asserting that this setting is at a human tech level and that electricity, lights, and infastructure are already commonplace somewhere. Is this a PMD world? Is it a human world? I suppose I'm not in the right to know by this point, but I do find your use of Volcanion and your weird steam-cosmology at the very least mildly interesting.

Well I guess it's fine. I really don't care about any of it. A general rule of thumb is that you don't want to write yourself into a situation where you need to do such a shameless infodump. You want to be able to organically seed all that exposition throughout the text, in dialogue and imagery and character interactions. This was a lot of points that could've been introduced in character, but you've blown your entire load right away and now the only things you can reveal about your world are minor or plot-relevant. And frankly I don't think you gave the reader a chance to get invested in the world before you gave them the entire world.

Okay yeah the Zangoose does just love talking.

Alright, fair enough. Since the Xatu are apparently rather important and sacred in the hierarchy of civilization, it makes sense that you would rescue any random Natu you found way up north and then immediately bolt before anyone assumed you were the one that hurt them.

Eh.

First of all, thank you for your honesty and your in-depth critique, I truly appreciate it. Assuming you're the same anon who said you dislike my optimism and marketing, I respect that, but you have to be like this if you're not gonna just give up with your head hung, I've faced enough rejection and failure as an author to know how I wanna promote myself in new ventures, though I get that especially on a place like here some people aren't gonna take to it. On that note, I'm not trying to combat your criticisms, just responding to points as I've always liked for feedback to be a discussion.

One of the first and most important lessons I learned when studying creative writing when I was in school was that the narrator is very important, for the very reasons you're critiquing. Most fledgling authors simply state things for the sake of stating them and project all of their imagery onto the narrator without ever actually considering the purpose or function of the narrator. I'm not gonna go spoiling my own story just to defend it, but what I'll say is that the narrator in the villainous plot is absolutely a character-via-narration and not just an objective statement vessel, and is deliberately different from the way Nathan's plotline is narrated (as his is narrated in-character). Nathan doesn't have the information of the Champion narrator, the Champion narrator is not Nathan, you get what I mean? Also, they're reflecting because it's the light of the plasma illuminating them, the runes themselves are not glowing, the shine is the reflection.

Fair enough. I can't say I care too much about traditional PMD plots, and for that matter I am wholly not interested in reading another one as opposed to a more exploratory work, but I understand that the PMD market mostly does not share that opinion. I am not a fan of stark mechanical interpretation, or some of the ways you've expressed worldbuilding or character. I think that your Volcanion/Enlightening-Steam angle is an interesting start. I do not care for your antagonist at all, am severely wary of him being a shitty game-term ripoff, and feel very little threat from him or his cronies. I think Zangoose is alright, and that your choice of species for the protagonist is interesting and has potential. I hope, of course, that you do not misuse the psychic typing as a cheap plot-device and easily-malleable convenience tool.

I am not interested in your story as it is. I will tell you, though, that a great many people will be, and if you continue to shill you have a high chance of becoming extremely popular. That is not praise, that is the reality of the kind of pulpy story you are trying to make. I would just hope that you don't follow the example of so many other popular common-denominator PMD authors and write a meandering story that goes on for hundreds and hundreds of thousands of words without ever meaningfully resolving.

I do not hateread because I do not have the time to read something I don't think is worth reading. You will have plenty of readers enough.

I'm a firm believer in everything panning out and no detail being useless when it comes to being an author, so I will say that those referential aspects of his character will definitely pay off, but I know some people might not love it. The cronies being goofy is definitely intentional though, The Champion's crew is not meant to immediately be intimidating, their whole nature is to creep up on you. Abducting and enslaving Volcanion is as mundane as taking a shower or going to the store for the them, there's no need to go edge-mode on them there. Also, Psychic types will not be given any special status, only certain individual Pokemon; the only all-out Type shenanigan going on is a special Water type blessing that allows fish/sea critter Water Types to survive out of water. I don't read other PMD stories, I don't write without purpose, and I don't tell stories without a destination in mind, I'm sorry you don't think it's worth reading but I'm 100% certain that I'll prove you wrong in that regard.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53157562
Not that anon, but another writefag who checked out your work. Your responses worry me somewhat for the future of this project.

>repeated refusal to elaborate due to 'spoilers'
Weasel behavior. The board's got spoiler tags; outright refusal to answer legitimate concerns like why a JRPG villain is talking like some neckbeard on /r/pokemon tells me either that you don't actually know or that you don't deem the question worth answering.

>plus it's something the series does.
Canon PMD isn't prose, so you shouldn't adapt everything one to one. I would prioritize the conventions of prose writing that an alleged professional author should be well familiar with over style-matching video game dialogue.

>Game Literalism
You are not writing for a video game. Not only is it trite and lazy to import wholesale gamey elements like the personality quiz or calling out move names, but it can really kill a reader's immersion to do such things.
>Recap
Oh no no no no. What fucking work of prose has ever included a "LAST TIME ON DRAGON BALL Z" recap? AO3 says you're 4.5k words in at 2/8 chapters. Is your target audience a bowl of goldfish? Who the fuck needs constant reminders of what happened circa four pages ago? I wouldn't defend such a thing in any circumstance but at an estimated final length of 18-20k words based on the current rate it's downright insulting to your reader.
>like a soap opera or ATLA
Neither of those things are prose. You are not writing a soap opera or a cartoon. You cannot freely borrow the conventions of other types of media and expect them to work well in the written word.

I don't want to resort to ad hominem, but your responses to this feedback do not fill me with confidence regarding your alleged published works. The matter of "kids' lit" being a separate entity from any other genre fiction is a rant for another time. To make a long story short I will simply point to Sturgeon's Law and say that being published is not necessarily saying much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53166917
If you're going that route, Beautifly has better Attack and Speed, evolves more than 10 levels earlier, and also learns Silver Wind more than 10 levels earlier, and Swarm boosts the power of the move even more. Masquerain has better natural bulk, paired with intimidate, but that's not saying much on a Bug/Flying type.

For Masquerain to have an advantage you'd need to keep it as a Surskit for longer to learn Bubblebeam to compete with the Grass special attacks Beautifly gets access to. Either that or resort to TM moves, but you have to wait until pretty late to even have the option for Blizzard or Water Pulse, and if you can afford Ice Beam from the Game Corner there are much better mons to give it to. Or you could buy Psychic from the Game Corner for even cheaper and teach that to Beautifly.

And of course there's the advantage of Wurmple being plentiful in the early game while Surskit is a 1% encounter in Ruby and Sapphire while being totally absent in Emerald. It's not even like it has a niche of an early game Water type if you didn't pick Mudkip, because there's also Lotad and Wingull.
I'm not saying it's terrible or useless, but Gamefreak could have certainly made it better given how rare it is.

>>53145444
As discussed in the smogon tier changes thread, Goodr should get recover. As it stands, it's a pokemon clearly designed to tank special hits, but complete lack of reliable recovery moves means it can't actually do that for very long before getting chipped down, meaning it doesn't really have a viable role that isn't done better by the other pseudolegendaries. Gastrodon, another slug-based pokemon, already gets recover, so it wouldn't be thematically unfitting. Alternatively, replace its hydration with rain dish for similar effect.
I'd also swap its attack and defense stats. Having higher defense than attack would fit with it being designed to be bulky, and the attack stat is kind of wasted now as it doesn't really have enough good physical moves to run a physical or mixed set. However, I don't think that would be strictly necessary. Just giving it some way to recover health would go a long way in making it actually have a competitive role.

>>53150664
This, but only kind of.

Pokemon STILL vary wildly in sizes. Look at how fucking big Starly is in PLA compared to SV. Avalugg is fucking comically miniscule in SV, but is correctly sized in SwSh. There's weird things like Charizard being big enough to be rideable in LGPE/SM/USUM (more akin to how everyone pictures Zard), but not being that large in SwSh and SV.

They keep changing their style of measurement for Pokemon too. Tropius is supposed to be 6'7 but is only a little over the players head in height, meaning theyre likely measuring it head to ass despite not doing so previously. In Colosseum, XD, PBR, and all other media, it's measured head to foot.

In PLA you had this weird fucking issue where the listed sizes absolutely did not match what they actually were. Pokemon with similar body plans (like Lucario and Lopunny) could have the same measurements, and be totally different heights. Even within the same fucking species, the longest Steelix (which is actually longer than its Alpha) is the exact same size as the Alpha.

Anyways, this is all to say, they do try to hold stubbornly to Dex sizes even when theyre obvious ass pulls, but are shitty and inconsistent with it.

I feel Tsareena should be grass/fighting,and it and its pre-evolution learn the stat-boosting dance moves. >"Fine, you do it if you're so goddamn smart" theme

Talonflame? No. Kindlewing
Etc.
>An item that you can see when naming your pokemon

Name it like your a scientist and then shorten it if it's too long
Latin for the animal that it is or a similar animal, plus a defining trait, feature, element, etc.
Simple example
>Pikachu
>Lightning Mouse, Fulger Mus
>Fulmus

I needed to try something and I've been wanting to try out a rocket-locke for a while, so I may start out a run next weekend if I finish Dead Space 2 by then.

The basics is that I can steal any pokemon from the trainer I battle first in an area (really interesting because if you can avoid trainers you have some control over the potential pools depending on trainer types). Also, to compensate for missing catches due to some areas having no trainers, I will allow myself to try capturing each gym's leader last pokemon.

But I need help deciding how to implement a dupes clause. I'm thinking that it only comes into play when the trainer I choose happens to only be carrying one single mon I already have. Because otherwise, if I'm against a trainer with 3 mons for example, and I skip the first 2 to fish for something better only to get a dupe, it just doesn't feel fair that I get to retry with another trainer: I chose to risk it and I should face the consequences.

Thoughts?

I'm sort of doing a soft-nuzlocke for BW and B2W2 since this will be the first time for them, I'm kind of in the dark on what's gonna happen and when. So I'll be using items and any ambush battles will be resets to last save so I can heal before hand.
By the by, anyone else absolutely loathe ambush Rival/Boss fights? I think they're just obnoxious and that's why I'm implementing it into the bullshit clause for these games, I'm not looking to get ganked on my way to an Pkmn Center because the game decides the best place to throw a boss at me is when my party is a 10~30% HP all around.
Maybe that makes some of you seethe but I played the other games with the benefit of foresight into ambushes and had a good time despite lost team members.

Gengar

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53148721
NTA but I always see people talk about how good Misdreavus is, are they really good?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53149318
I would say so. They lack the setup moves in Sinnoh that make some competitive sets great (Nasty Plot is HGSS tutor only, Calm Mind is Battle Frontier only), but they have good Speed and Sp. Atk, and work as a great TM dump (Shadow Ball, Thunderbolt, Psychic, Dark Pulse), which is the sort of coverage you would want for a Specs user in DPP

Downsides are the low encounter rate (just Eterna Forest and Lost Tower), Pearl exclusive and that Dusk Stone takes a bit to show up, but it's a solid choice considering the other encounters on those areas aren't as great except for Gastly

Also, Dusk Stone in HGSS is post-game only, which makes them a lot less useful in those games

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From a commercial point of view the kid is right, this series is immortal.
Gameplay-wise GF never managed to evolve past the gameplay mechanics created for Pokémon Red and Green to fit the technical limitation that the Game Boy had. The result is that the newer games still have the same 25+ years old battle system and combined with an unpolished 3D open map it gives a jarring experience. Game Freak never learned to move beyond developing 2D games for portable consoles and it shows even in their non-Pokémon titles.
The story has never been a focal point of the Pokémon series but from a lore standpoint this series died after Gen 2 which was the only generation that has been a proper sequel and expansion to the previous generation. From Gen 3 and beyond every region was self-contained and had a focus on the Pokèmon mythology of those regions that made the basis of the plot of Ruby and Sapphire and beyond. Which from a commercial point of view it proved to be the most efficient system for making Pokémon games every 3 years compared to the development hell that the titles directed by Satoshi Tajiri used to have. However on the other end this new working process has destroyed the chance of creating a coherent lore to the series. This can be seen in the Gen 7 games that made an effort to mesh together the information introduced in the previous generations with an added focus to the multiverse but by doing that the final result were a giant amount of contradictions because every bit of lore that got introduced in the previous generation weren't meant to be a part of a coherent system of the Pokèmon multiuniverse. As a result the only solution GF to solve this problem is to revisit the lore from the ground up with the inevitable conseguence of alienating several bunches of fans that grew up with this series. Since GF and TPC are trying to get as much sales as possible, this series is stuck with a mess of a lore that doesn't stand on its own

>>53121913
Gardevoir's body is sort of fake.
It is in both the amorphous and human-like egg-groups, in spite of being one of the most anthropomorphic of nearly any Pokemon.
I reckon it was previously a far more inhuman form previously, akin to something like Reiniculus or Mismagius.
However, it has attained a shape which is human-like to aid in its relating to humans. Human's are more likely to trust something as serene and familiar as a Gardevoir or Kirlia, than they are a floating blob.
For instance, its legs are more or less fake. It moves through levitation, and the limbs are far too spindly to support its weight.
Ralt's design is also far less humanoid, having a torso and legs which fuse into each other with a trailing portion, as if it is not experienced enough to maintain sufficiently humanoid extremities.
It's real body seems to be the head(Which remains similarly sized through each evolution), and the horn/heart through which it uses its powers.
Why it is so interested in humans is up to interpretation.
However, the line is intrinsically involved with humanity somehow, with Kirlia evolving due to contact with a humans positive emotions, and the noted protectivity of a Gardevoir towards its trainer (The pokedex stresses that this is towards its trainer, not merely just its loved ones)
Any thoughts why?

>>53129324
That's about two-thirds where I went with pokeballs in my stories.

There is a power cell system that requires some degree of maintenance. Certain modes and activities have different amounts of drain to consider. And a recalled pokemon is in a somewhat dreamlike state, but that affects mostly the perception of time, and doesn't prohibit willful action or recognizing the outside world by sound, vibration, or in some cases other pokemon-specific senses. The longer a pokemon is in, however, the more vague and tranquilized the mental state becomes. And being reconstituted after a long period inside leads to significant disorientation both due to the time effect and the pokemon's mind and body being reformed in the state of recollection despite consciousness having proceeded, causing a moment of having two thoughts—then and now—at the same time.

>>53121913
>Why do Pokemon obey humans, and not create civilizations of their own?
Hardly canon but I always considered the mystery dungeon series an answer to a human-less pokemon world.

It comes down to pokemon just naturally attaching themselves to strong leaders. Weaker pokemon would group together to form fairly low tech civilizations with the stronger pokemon acting as leaders or protectors of group.

This tends to either be a low tech village like pokemon square protected by a pokemon guild or something more tribal/pack-like where a strong pokemon has control over a large territory like a desert or a mountain range.
Either way they rely on those stronger than them so they are more able to concentrate with their day to day needs. Any complex social structures arise out of necessity not ambition or greed.

Which is why Pokemon are naturally driven to humans as we are creatures of ambition and desire. The pokemon-trainer bond comes naturally from their desire to follow a strong leader.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Arceus is an extra-dimensional being from the same realm as Eternatus and Deoxys (and only those two, even Ultra Space is an offshoot of Mew).

It created Mew as a genetic progenitor to "pokeform" Earth, and its weird offspring were highly-mutable and super-adaptable creatures (hence evolution) that served as a single invasive species that took over the planet. It's why most of them can interbreed. One by one, Pokemon took over ecological niches on the planet by replacing and outperforming everything they encountered. Even fossil Pokemon are the result of Pokemon trying to copy fossils. Finally, it met its match with humanity. Despite trying to make exaggerated caricatures of different types of humans or myths and "gods" that people imagined, the Pokemon were not able to fully wrest humanity's control over the planet.

Arceus saw humanity's value when the ancient champion referred to in lore somehow saved the something or other, and grew to feel guilty over seeding Earth with its all-consuming offspring. It decided to oversee the symbiotic relationship formed by the two distinct lines of Pokemon and humanity. Mew, for its part, had long learned to control its own fissionable nature and stopped creating new organisms. And yes, Dittos are failed attempts at cloning Mew. It wasn't until human DNA was added as a stabilizer that Mewtwo was created.

Ultra Megapolis is, and never was, an "alien planet". It's the future of the main timeline, ala Future Trunks timeline. Only Ultra Space have properties to be called alien planets.
There's enough evidence to assume Necrozma created the UBs to rebel against Arceus, and the Tapus were specifically created to stop Necrozma.

Necrozma was created to be a being of emptiness and only be a way to refract and transfer light throughout the universe, until it rebelled. It brought the original Cosmog line to near extinction in the far past, eating enough to become Ultra Necrozma, with his powers becoming so strange from his universal feast on these species of Pokemon that it affected other inanimate/living things and turned them into UBs.
Kukui said in the beginning of USUM that "People and Pokemon united against darkness long ago", that darkness being Necrozma stealing light.
Necrozma was defeated by everyone in the past, and the UBs were locked away in either pocket dimensions or far away planets unreachable by man or Pokemon, unless it happened to be related to the Cosmog line, which Necrozma gained the powers of by eating so many.
Anyways, Lusamine in Sun and Moon opened Ultra Space up and the UBs escaped, but this woke Necrozma up as well in SM.
Canonically, the player did not catch Necrozma in SM, so Necrozma killed the player, fused with the respective version's legendary, and wiped out a good portion of humanity and Pokemon before they united again to seal Necrozma up in a tower they constructed to give light to the rest of the world and seperate the two legendaries.

There are multiple Mewtwos because clones have been made from the DNA of the original Mewtwo.

The og Mewtwo was expensive and difficult because it took actual Mew DNA and fucked it up in just the right way to make an insane demigod, and the process to do that again would be one-in-a-million since all the lab research was destroyed. However making a clone of an already existing pokemon is much easier (albiet still expensive), and getting hold of trace Mewtwo DNA would be slightly easier than hunting down more Mew DNA. These Mewtwo copies are still strong, but functionally weaker than the original, and explains why there's one randomly in Kalos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53121913
The Pokemon world largely is a utopia, due to Electric- and Fire-type Pokemon being a source of infinite energy, and due to technology that allows for the instantaneous transportation of matter over large distances. The latter allows human settlements to be spaced further apart without much in the way of infrastructure, resulting in vast swathes of untamed wilderness between towns and cities.

There were wars in the past, but they tended to be fought due to political reasons rather than for resources, and the matter-transportation invention quickly eliminated any lingering need for the latter. The last major conflict was the war Lt. Surge was involved in, and since then, the concept of physical conflict has become extremely gouache among people in general. It's why the evil teams are so looked down upon, even if they're just the equivalent of local hooligans.

Humans and Pokemon evolved alongside each other. Humans have developed a passive ability to assert powerful influence on Pokemon, which accumulates as they spend time around each other. This explains why Pokemon so enthusiastically obey humans, why Pokemon are generally very reluctant to harm humans, and why Pokemon seem to incorporate human concepts into their forms (objectmons, Pokemon with certain cultural motifs, etc.).

Aside from this, humans in the Pokemon world are also generally more fantastical than regular humans. The innate influence that humans have over Pokemon is sometimes especially strong, allowing for the development of psychic powers between receptive Psychic-type Pokemon and even other humans. Mediums can be trained to be temporarily "possessed" by certain Ghost-type Pokemon, gaining paranormal ability while remaining dominant over their own consciousnesses. However, being possessed by more than one Ghost-type Pokemon or a particularly-powerful Pokemon (say, a fully-evolved Gengar) drastically increases the chances of the medium no longer being in control of one's body.

>Horn: dragonite loses the horn and gains antennae for no reason.
>Tail: the tail of dragonair is similar to a rattlesnake. It loses this design element when evolving for no reason.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

>Wiki
https://pokeclicker.miraheze.org/wiki/Home_Page

You're supposed to make most of your diamonds by chaining underground daily deals.
Which is funny, because this is technically exploiting a poor RNG algorithm that makes the random deals predictable, but the devs just let players rely on it instead of balancing the minigame. In a recent patch, they even went out of their way to make sure an update didn't fuck up the 100 days long chain their Discord bot came up with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53135996
>technically exploiting a poor RNG algorithm
how exactly is that the case?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53136204
I don't know the details, just that the deals that appear each day are supposed to be random; there is not a fixed schedule. But at some point someone figured out how to predict the randomness, probably because the code responsible is not too complex. With that information, someone else made a bot that forecasts future deals and can be found at the official Discord. That's where the chains that appear in this thread from time to time come from.
So it's technically an exploit, but "officially" recognized, in part because this way the devs don't feel the need to make the Underground not shit, but also because they don't want to deal with their "hardcore" players throwing a hissy fit if they mess with their chains.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53136681
The deals were intended to be the same for everyone each day, but without a hardcoded schedule to follow. As far as I know, this isn't possible to make unpredictable unless a server is involved holding some secret used in the generation.

>>53163379

From IGN's review in 2000:

"All battles take place in closed-off arenas with simple backdrops inspired by the anime series. The environments are pretty unimpressive -- but that's for a reason. The polygonal Pokémon are where it's at. These soft-skinned beauties are not only highly detailed and look exactly like their TV counterparts, they also move with such convincing animation that it seems likely that Nintendo has found a way to motion-capture real-life Pokémon. The bird animations are especially impressive and each of the 151 Pokémon has a unique (and often hilarious) "fainting" animation as well. There are so many neat details, that it's impossible to list them all. Grimer and Muk drip and ooze as they try to maintain their shape, Cloyster's horns rotate, Venusaur gets bloodshot eyes when it's in trouble, Jolteon shakes its head and stumbles backwards after a hit and Lickitung is at its most disturbing. Some of the size differences that weren't apparent in the Game Boy versions are also beautifully reproduced. Just pit a Gyarados against a Magikarp and you'll understand... And best of all, the framerate is rock solid.

The attack graphics are equally impressive, with colorful particle animations and screen-shaking special effects. Like in the Game Boy games, the Pokémon never actually physically "touch" each other -- which comes as somewhat of a disappointment. Luckily, all the elemental attacks and their effects on the Pokémon are shown in their full glory, so it isn't really that big of a deal if you can't actually see two Pokémon make contact with some of the more boring moves like Slash and Stomp.

Overall, the game's graphical presentation is top notch, though it naturally can't compete with adventure or platform games since it lacks environment detail."
